==Capture==
==Capture==
â
[[File:Safe house in Faisalabad where Abu Zubaydah was captured.jpg|thumb|Abu Zubaydah was captured in this [[safe house in Faisalabad]], together with half a dozen individuals who would later face charges before [[Guantanamo military commission]]s.]]
+
[[File:Safe house in Faisalabad where Abu Zubaydah was captured.jpg|thumb|{{deletable image-caption|Wednesday, 12 January 2011}} Abu Zubaydah was captured in this [[safe house in Faisalabad]], together with half a dozen individuals who would later face charges before [[Guantanamo military commission]]s.]]
It is unclear how the Government found Abu Zubaydah. U.S. officials claimed he was tracked down after making a phone call to al-Qaeda leaders in Yemen.<ref name="TedBridis">[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-52457420.html Ted Bridis ''U.S. Will Seek Death Penalty In Spy Case'' The Columbian, April 20, 2002] (Highbeam News Database Link, requires free membership)</ref> However, this has been questioned by a CIA official who stated that the U.S. paid $10 million to the Pakistani government, who had in turn bribed the information on his whereabouts from a local driver in [[Faisalabad]].<ref name=mayer/> Pakistani intelligence discovered that he was traveling in disguise as a [[burka]]-clad woman.<ref name=mayer/> Saudi Arabian officials claimed Abu Zubaydah was captured after intelligence gleaned during an interrogation by their GSS.<ref name="Nowaf Obaid">[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-404238.html Nowaf Obaid, ''The Saudisâ Fight Too: Weâre on the same side in the war on terror'' The Washington Post, December 26, 2002] (Highbeam News Database Link, requires free membership)</ref> It was also reported in 2008 that [[Deuce Martinez]], a CIA analyst, had played an integral role in narrowing down Abu Zubaydahâs supposed hideouts to the 14 targeted by the joint raids.<ref name="ScottShaneInside9/11Mastermind">[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/22/washington/22ksm.html?_r=1&pagewanted=1 Scott Shane, ''Inside a 9/11 mastermindâs interrogation'' New York Times, June 22, 2008]</ref>
It is unclear how the Government found Abu Zubaydah. U.S. officials claimed he was tracked down after making a phone call to al-Qaeda leaders in Yemen.<ref name="TedBridis">[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-52457420.html Ted Bridis ''U.S. Will Seek Death Penalty In Spy Case'' The Columbian, April 20, 2002] (Highbeam News Database Link, requires free membership)</ref> However, this has been questioned by a CIA official who stated that the U.S. paid $10 million to the Pakistani government, who had in turn bribed the information on his whereabouts from a local driver in [[Faisalabad]].<ref name=mayer/> Pakistani intelligence discovered that he was traveling in disguise as a [[burka]]-clad woman.<ref name=mayer/> Saudi Arabian officials claimed Abu Zubaydah was captured after intelligence gleaned during an interrogation by their GSS.<ref name="Nowaf Obaid">[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-404238.html Nowaf Obaid, ''The Saudisâ Fight Too: Weâre on the same side in the war on terror'' The Washington Post, December 26, 2002] (Highbeam News Database Link, requires free membership)</ref> It was also reported in 2008 that [[Deuce Martinez]], a CIA analyst, had played an integral role in narrowing down Abu Zubaydahâs supposed hideouts to the 14 targeted by the joint raids.<ref name="ScottShaneInside9/11Mastermind">[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/22/washington/22ksm.html?_r=1&pagewanted=1 Scott Shane, ''Inside a 9/11 mastermindâs interrogation'' New York Times, June 22, 2008]</ref>
